{"comments": {"id": 13484, "count": 84, "talk_id": 1477}, "threadId": 13484, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "1477", "description": "In this short talk, TED Fellow Sarah Parcak introduces the field of "space archaeology" -- using satellite images to search for clues to the lost sites of past civilizations.", "event": "TED2012", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Sarah Parcak: Archaeology from space", "slug": "sarah_parcak_archeology_from_space", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1164", "slug": "sarah_parcak", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Sarah", "lastname": "Parcak", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Satellite archaeologist + TED Prize winner", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/0b7c4b4d43b97a2f7c6984eaeb522a118dc68c88_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Her laptop brims with satellite images pitted with thousands of black dots, evidence of excavations across Egypt where looters have tunneled in search of mummies, jewelry and other valuables prized by collectors, advertised in auction catalogs and trafficked on eBay, a criminal global black market estimated in the billions of dollars.", "whotheyare": "Like a modern-day Indiana Jones, Sarah Parcak uses satellite images to locate lost ancient sites. The winner of the 2016 TED Prize, her wish is to protect the world’s shared cultural heritage.", "whylisten": "

There may be hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of undiscovered ancient sites across the globe. Sarah Parcak wants to locate them. As a space archaeologist, she analyzes high-resolution imagery collected by satellites in order to identify subtle changes to the Earth’s surface that might signal man-made features hidden from view. A TED Senior Fellow and a National Geographic Explorer, Parcak wrote the textbook on satellite archaeology and founded the Laboratory for Global Observation at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Her goal: to make the world's invisible history visible once again.

In Egypt, Parcak's techniques have helped locate 17 potential pyramids, and more than 3,100 potential forgotten settlements. She's also made discoveries in the Viking world (as seen in the PBS Nova special, Vikings Unearthed) and across the Roman Empire (as shown in the BBC documentary, Rome’s Lost Empire). Her methods also offer a new way to understand how ancient sites are being affected by looting and urban development. By satellite-mapping Egypt and comparing sites over time, Parcak has noted a 1,000 percent increase in looting since 2009. It’s likely that millions of dollars worth of artifacts are stolen each year. Parcak hopes that, through her work, unknown sites can be protected to preserve our rich, vibrant history.

As the winner of the 2016 TED Prize, Parcak asked the world to help in this important work. By building a citizen science platform for archaeology, GlobalXplorer.org, Parcak invites anyone with an internet connection to help find the next potential looting pit or unknown tomb. GlobalXplorer launched on January 30, 2017, with volunteers working together to map Peru. Other countries will follow, as the platform democratizes discovery and makes satellite-mapping rapid and cost-effective. 

 

"}], "url": "https://www.ted.com/talks/sarah_parcak_archeology_from_space", "viewed_count": 1087373, "talks": [{"recommendations": {"status": "approved", "headline": "Sarah Parcak recommends", "blurb": "These five books open doors to our shared human history. The first paints a vivid picture of why archaeologists do what we do, and the rest pushed me to reexamine my preconceived notions about specific periods of time in antiquity.", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": null, "type": "recommendation", "rec_lists": [{"title": "", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Lives in Ruins: Archaeologists and the Seductive Lure of Human Rubble*", "blurb": "Marilyn Johnson is a delightful writer. She follows the story of archaeologists working in different parts of the world, and asks: Why do people do this? What guides people to travel to godforsaken places all over the world and spend all this time preparing to go into the field when the risk is so great and the payoff is often so low? The answer: all of us are driven by our passion. She does a beautiful job of explaining why we do the hard work of archaeology.", "note": "Marilyn Johnson Harper Perennial, 2015", "link_url": "http://geni.us/1Kfr", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome*", "blurb": "This lively book tells the story of what made the Roman Empire tick, using stories of everyday life. Mary Beard shares stories of Julius Caesar, Cleopatra, Hannibal and other boldfaced names, but also writes about those usually forgotten in the narrative of Rome -- the slaves, the women, all the people who were conquered along the way. Beard writes with humor and wit. Be careful. You'll be pulled in, and may wake up wearing a toga.", "note": "Mary Beard Liveright, 2015", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0871404230/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*1177 B.C.: The Year Civilization Collapsed*", "blurb": "In 1177 B.C., many different ancient cultures thrived in the cradle of civilization. It was the Bronze Age, and all was well -- art and architecture were at a peak, knowledge was highly valued, and economies boomed. But then, a group called the 'Sea Peoples' invaded Egypt, and everything turned around. The Egyptians fought them off, but their society was deeply weakened. With that vacuum of power and a major earthquake, civilizations started to fall -- and quickly. Cline weaves a masterful tale of a time period of major climate change and collapse that has many lessons for us today.", "note": "Eric H. Cline Princeton University Press, 2015", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0691168385/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Think Like an Egyptian: 100 Hieroglyphs*", "blurb": "Written by the greatest living Egyptologist, this wonderful, short book will take you inside the heads of the ancient Egyptians and show you how they thought. You’ll see the hieroglyphs for concepts like 'sun,' 'to love' and 'body,' and you'll learn the history and evolution of their meanings plus their pronunciations, in case you’d like to pepper them into conversations.", "note": "Barry Kemp Plume, 2005", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0452287014/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Scanning the Pharaohs: CT Imaging of the New Kingdom Royal Mummies*", "blurb": "Mummies. Kings. Technology. What's not to love? Written by one of the most flamboyant characters in modern Egyptology, you will be taken inside the bodies of ancient kings and queens from the eighteenth to twentieth Dynasties, which are now housed at the Cairo Museum. The best part? The detailed projections of the mummy's facial features.", "note": "Zahi Hawass and Sahar Saleem The American University in Cairo Press, 2015", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/9774166736/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": null}]}]}, "more_resources": [{"status": "approved", "headline": "Feel the thrill of discovery", "blurb": "Sarah Parcak has a bold TED Prize wish: to build a citizen science platform for archaeology and train a 21st century virtual army to help analyze satellite imagery. ", "link_url": "http://globalxplorer.org/", "image_url": "https://page-builder.ted.com/system/baubles/files/000/005/179/original/globalxplorer.png", "visible_url": "globalxplorer.org", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "EXPLORE", "type": "external_website"}, {"status": "approved", "headline": "Sarah Parcak crowdsources archaeology", "blurb": "“I wish for us to discover the millions of unknown archaeological sites across the globe, to find and protect the world's hidden heritage.”", "link_url": "https://www.ted.com/participate/ted-prize/prize-winning-wishes/globalxplorer", "image_url": "", "visible_url": "TED Prize", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "TED PRIZE 2016", "type": "external_website"}, {"status": "approved", "headline": "Calling all GlobalXplorers: Get ready to go to India", "blurb": "GlobalXplorer, the citizen science platform created by satellite archaeologist Sarah Parcak, is heading to India!", "link_url": "https://blog.ted.com/calling-all-globalxplorers-get-ready-to-go-to-india/", "image_url": "", "visible_url": "ideas.ted.com", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "READ MORE", "type": "external_website"}, {"status": "approved", "headline": "Gallery: Mysteries in satellite images", "blurb": "Archaeology is a puzzle, made exponentially easier with satellite imagery. Some mysteries Sarah Parcak's space-age methods have helped solve.", "link_url": "http://ideas.ted.com/gallery-archaeological-mysteries-hidden-in-satellite-images/", "image_url": "", "visible_url": [{"id": "1164", "slug": "sarah_parcak", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Sarah", "lastname": "Parcak", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Satellite archaeologist + TED Prize winner", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/0b7c4b4d43b97a2f7c6984eaeb522a118dc68c88_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Her laptop brims with satellite images pitted with thousands of black dots, evidence of excavations across Egypt where looters have tunneled in search of mummies, jewelry and other valuables prized by collectors, advertised in auction catalogs and trafficked on eBay, a criminal global black market estimated in the billions of dollars.", "whotheyare": "Like a modern-day Indiana Jones, Sarah Parcak uses satellite images to locate lost ancient sites. The winner of the 2016 TED Prize, her wish is to protect the world’s shared cultural heritage.", "whylisten": "

There may be hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of undiscovered ancient sites across the globe. Sarah Parcak wants to locate them. As a space archaeologist, she analyzes high-resolution imagery collected by satellites in order to identify subtle changes to the Earth’s surface that might signal man-made features hidden from view. A TED Senior Fellow and a National Geographic Explorer, Parcak wrote the textbook on satellite archaeology and founded the Laboratory for Global Observation at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Her goal: to make the world's invisible history visible once again.

In Egypt, Parcak's techniques have helped locate 17 potential pyramids, and more than 3,100 potential forgotten settlements. She's also made discoveries in the Viking world (as seen in the PBS Nova special, Vikings Unearthed) and across the Roman Empire (as shown in the BBC documentary, Rome’s Lost Empire). Her methods also offer a new way to understand how ancient sites are being affected by looting and urban development. By satellite-mapping Egypt and comparing sites over time, Parcak has noted a 1,000 percent increase in looting since 2009. It’s likely that millions of dollars worth of artifacts are stolen each year. Parcak hopes that, through her work, unknown sites can be protected to preserve our rich, vibrant history.

As the winner of the 2016 TED Prize, Parcak asked the world to help in this important work. By building a citizen science platform for archaeology, GlobalXplorer.org, Parcak invites anyone with an internet connection to help find the next potential looting pit or unknown tomb. GlobalXplorer launched on January 30, 2017, with volunteers working together to map Peru. Other countries will follow, as the platform democratizes discovery and makes satellite-mapping rapid and cost-effective. 

 

"}], "speaker_name": "Sarah Parcak", "tags": ["Egypt", "TED Fellows", "exploration", "history", "science", "space", "technology", "ancient world", "Africa", "collaboration", "innovation", "anthropology", "computers", "NASA", "geology", "archaeology"], "title": "Archaeology from space", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1087373}]}

title: Archaeology from space
